Edit: Snark aside, since so many people are asking: You can't buy a gun anywhere in Illinois without a FOID card, which can take up to 2 months.  Also, you can buy a gun in Indiana with an Illinois Driver's licence, but the gun must be shipped to a firearms dealer in Illinois, where you can only pick it up with your FOID. The underlying crux of Garfield's novels is that the vigilante is supposed to be this unassuming guy.

author: keinish77

text: The trailer really doesn't feel like the movie is going to have the tone of the first film, which is unfortunate. Plus, there's the fact that Willis doesn't really pull off the unassuming surgeon look. Paul Kersey wasn't an action hero (at least not in the first film nor the novel) he was just an unassuming guy who given his history as a conscientious objector was the last person anyone would suspect was a vigilante blowing people away. Kersey is a broken man, who does terrible things because the world is even more broken; something that a lot of people at that time could identify with and only got worse as the decade went along (Bernie Goetz). Given the fact the after decades of violent crime having a general downward trend only to start skyrocketing again last year, and the fact that the 2016 Chicago homicides is highest in 19 years and that the city has had over 400 homicides this year already I feel like a Death Wish movie could totally work in a modern Chicago. Unfortunately, this movie doesn't look like it can do that justice.

text: John Mccain proved what most of us somewhat intelligent people already knew. He proved that liberalism does indeed cause brain cancer.   The sad part is, one of the tweets that sparked this came from a FILM critic. I honestly don't think he's ever seen an action movie. Since when is the whole revenge/vengeance/vigilante justice trope an alt-right thing? Those plot devices are extremely old, very common and overused out the ass. A guy getting wronged only to seek revenge by killing everyone who stands in his path to kill the guy(s) directly responsible. We've seen this 1000 times over. It's basically the gold standard for action movies. It's also the plot for Django Unchained, you know a black slave getting released only to kill every last white dude for kidnapping his wife. Oh and John Wick. They killed his fucking dog! In the case of this remake his wife is murdered and daughter is raped and beaten. He gets angry because the cops don't do anything and he's living in a city where crime is out of control. (kinda like real life Chicago) So he takes it upon himself, you know kinda like THE PUNISHER.

text: This is stupid. Look, Death Wish was written at a time when the crime rate in the United States was at it's absolute highest and the danger of being mugged was a very real, very daily thing. In 2017 with crime being at an all time LOW it just doesn't have the same impact.  Also did the trailer say that he shot someone for a car jacking? In the original movie he baited violent criminals, not property thieves. It is closer to the original novel where Paul Kersey just shot everyone who even LOOKED like a criminal...with the message being that vigilantism is wrong.  Let's see how they'll mismatch this movie.

text: I'm a fan of the original Death Wish series (and I feel that a lot of critics were way too simplistic in their reaction to the original film), and I have to say that I hope that the full movie will be better than the trailer. The trailer isn't awful, and contrary to what some critics have said, I don't see how it's "alt-right," but I am getting the feeling here that the filmmakers do not understand the original. I'm not saying that there's no room for creative license, it's just one of those things where I ask "what's the point of remaking a classic?"  For one thing, I really hate the choice of music in this trailer. Don't get me wrong, Back in Black is a great song, but its use is such a cliche at this point and it's not fitting at all, especially if you've seen the original film. On top of that, in the original, Kersey was a more reluctant vigilante. In fact, he didn't even really become a vigilante at first, he just happened to be in the wrong place at the wrong time (multiple times, actually) and he defended himself, rather than seeking out criminals. Like I said, I hope the full movie will be better. If they make his character arc feel more natural so that it works with what we're seeing here, then I won't be complaining.

text: This looks really good, but a few things about this autistic comment section:  1: After watching this trailer multiple times and reading the main storyline, I can conclude that this movie has nothing to do with conservative politics. While it could be viewed that way, it only shows what it's like nowadays, which is rather conservative. Having someone buy a gun in a movie doesn't make it conservative.  2: I have not seen ONE liberal in this comment section, and yet I've seen so many conservatives insulting and saying "take that liberals! I bet you're all so upset!" No. We're not. I'm not. I'm more of a moderate than a liberal, and while I wish there was better gun control, I think the premise of this movie is pretty fucking awesome.  Thank you for anyone who took the time to read this, and I'm not gonna reply to any tumors who make shit points

text: When I first heard about this, I thought, "Great. Did we really need to remake the 1974 movie?" When I saw Bruce Willis was in it, I thought, "OK, so now Bruce is at the age to play Charles Bronson's character from the 74 version and relive his 'Die Hard' glory days. Still not interested." But then I heard that progressive socialists were calling this some alt-right thing and I decided to watch the trailer. Well, at least they are consistent. The progressive socialists of the 70s decried the original 'Death Wish' movie as well for the same reasons as today, only there was no scary "alt-right" back then, just "get tough on crime" conservatives.   Still not sure if I'll actually go see this or not. Maybe.

text: Vigilante justice and revenge/vengeance tropes are way, overused, it definitely isn't an "alt-right fantasy." Guy gets wronged, goes ham, kills everyone. Nothing new here, not even SJWs poisoning everything under the sun is new. However, liberals never stop surprising me with the stupid shit they say and complain about.   Batman. John Wick. Django Unchained.  Weird how those movies with the same exact plot isn't racist. Hell, you can argue Django is racist towards whites. No one did though because we aren't retarded.   It's almost as if the studio knew SJWs would spew idiocy and cry out racism. So they decided to go against statistical facts and throw in a disproportionate amount of white guys. 62% of Chicago is filled with hispanics and blacks. Chicago has the highest gun violence stats in the country. Blacks/hispanics are also disproportionately impacted by  poverty. Point of all of that is he's in a crime ridden, poor part of Chicago most of the people he shot should have been black, because most of the criminals should be black, statistically speaking.   In the trailer he killed 5 white guys, one black guy and one hispanic guy. The black group he came across, he only gunned down the main leader. If this movie is racist, it's racist towards white people since that's a disproportionate amount considering the location. He's killing PEOPLE because they are criminals. Not killing people because of their  race. Following the literal definition of the word 'racist' it's impossible. Leave it to liberals to argue against the dictionary. But they use feels, not reals. Even if it was mostly black people, that still wouldn't be racist, it would be statistically accurate.  *The people crying racism are in favor of disproportionately villainizing more white people to hide the fact that it would actually be statistically accurate if it were mostly black criminals.* Looks like some people should look in the mirror to find the actual racist.

text: I am glad to see Bruce w. Taking over for Iconic Charles Bronson. BUT...I am not happy at Eli Roth for director. I think he will take the story down a more violent/horror path rather than the philosophically torn- slowly changing -character that Bronson did in the original. The original was not just about revenge, but about whether violence is needed/justified in fighting evil men. It was one of the first vigilante movies where protagonist is a "normal" guy, not a mercenary, cowboy, police officer, soldier, ect. I want to see this movie in a theater... but... after SOOOOOO many heartbreaks by Hollywood...dare i trust again?

text: The White version of Shaft? I stay in Chicago, not too long ago we had a story about officers who were acting as a gang with badges. They were prostituting women, selling narcotics, and physically assaulting competition. I don't like bringing race into this but I'm going to answer the forbidden question. Yes, these officers were all White. About a year before that in Chicago we had a Captain that got caught and later admitted to forcing young black males to take plea deals on crimes he knew they didn't commit. One method he used was not giving the falsely arrested food or water for weeks or until they signed the documents. My point is when he went looking for crooks he should've stayed in the police station. No matter how me, you or aliens feel about what I said above. It doesn't change the fact this still happened during this generation, not the very racist 60s, the 70s, 80s. This happened in the 2000s, there's no civilian to blame. I didn't mean to bring race into it. I was really trying to say the bad guys in Chicago may be the ones that say they're there to protect you so Bruce start your search there.

text: A cartoonish remake of an unusual but not extraordinary 1974 film starring Charles Bronson.  This is at least the second time Bruce Willis has been involved in a tacky remake of a 1970's action film. In 1997, he and Richard Gere started in "The Jackal", which was a pale imitation of the highly acclaimed 1973 suspense film "Day of the Jackal" starring Edward Fox.  This new version of Death Wish looks like a grab bag of politically correct villains and storylines. Bruce Willis does not fit the role of Paul Kersey at all.  Is this rehashed and reheated tripe the best that Hollywood can manage to produce these days?

text: Chicago has the strictest gun laws but the most gun violence. Does that mean that less guns = more violence? Well, travel about 2 seconds just outside of Chicago you have some very loose gun laws  in the country. Not hard to take them back into Chicago once you get one. So it's actually a case where you got a large city, with a level of organized crime, and large sections of both rich and poor but it's actually not hard to get a gun. All you gotta do is travel a couple minutes and there's guns up for grabs. I'm not pro or anti-gun. I'd probably get one myself if I felt like I needed one. But what I do hate is the bullshit propaganda people put out on the topic. You'll never solve an issue if you're distracted by bullshit, but bullshit is just such an easy way to get people on your side that people will never stop using it either.

text: NO!NO! I'm old school. This is one of my favorite classics. When I first heard of the trailer, I said cool; I can see Bruce Willis playing the quiet, heavy hearted middle aged widower who takes vengeance on the streets that fed off of his wife and little girl. But this crap looks like a pretty, light hearted super hero film. Death wish 1974 was dark, very dark. Charles Bronson's version was a nervous wreck, who slowly gains the confidence of a vigilante; who was a creep in the night, a shadow, so much that no one knew him enough to be considered as a hero. text: I have a bad feeling this is not going to the cool, calm, collected, covert, yet compassionate killer that Kersey was.  That scene in the garage tells me so.  Kersey wasn't a fan of torture.  In fact, the violence shook him so much he vomited after the first killing.  In fact, I think Kersey would have tried to push the mechanic to the point the mechanic's rage caused him to dislodge the jack.  The antihero is supposed to be someone you understand fully, but can't root for, any jokes usually don't work.  Also, considering that the Death Wish series brought shock value to the screen (the start of Death Wish II earned it censorship from many countries you'd consider "Free"), what will this film offer?  Suppose I'll have to wait for March 1st and see if I'm right or wrong.

text: Probably one of the most enjoyable action movies ever made and it has 17% on Rotten Tomatoes. Critics are reviewing this film not on whether it's a good movie or not, but on whether it agrees with their political ideologies. A movie about a straight guy protecting his conventional and perfect family with guns against violent criminals is too much for some people to stomach. I've seen people berate the movie on dialogue where Willis says it's a man's job to protect his family, I mean ffs that is EXACTLY what a man is supposed to do. People dislike it because it "suggests that the best answer to crime is to defend yourself with force", YES of course it is, people have a right to protect themselves. I don't know what's happening in America but it's ridiculous. Here's to all the snowflakes scared shitless by the thought of a gun.
